## Problem 1 - 68-95-99 rule

- Given a mean of 27 and a standard deviation of 3, 68% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 27 and a standard deviation of 3, 95% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 27 and a standard deviation of 3, 99.7% of the data fall within what range?


## Problem 1 - Solution

- 68% of the data fall within one standard deviation of the mean. So the range is 24 to 30. (27-3 to 27+3)

- 95% of the data fall within two standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 21 to 33. (27-6 to 27+6)

- 99.7% of the data fall within three standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 18 to 36. (27-9 to 27+9)

## Problem 2 - 68-95-99 rule

- Given a mean of 1315 and a standard deviation of 10, 68% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 1315 and a standard deviation of 10, 95% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 1315 and a standard deviation of 10, 99.7% of the data fall within what range?

## Problem 2 - Solution

- 68% of the data fall within one standard deviation of the mean. So the range is 1305 to 1325. (1315-10 to 1315+10)

- 95% of the data fall within two standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 1295 to 1335. (1315-20 to 1315+20)

- 99.7% of the data fall within three standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 1285 to 1345. (1315-30 to 1315+30)

## Problem 3 - 68-95-99 rule

- Given a mean of 3 and a standard deviation of .03, 68% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 3 and a standard deviation of .03, 95% of the data fall within what range?

- Given a mean of 3 and a standard deviation of .03, 99.7% of the data fall within what range?

## Problem 3 - Solution

- 68% of the data fall within one standard deviation of the mean. So the range is 2.97 to 3.03. (3-.03 to 3+.03)

- 95% of the data fall within two standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 2.94 to 3.06. (3-.06 to 3+.06)

- 99.7% of the data fall within three standard deviations of the mean. So the range is 2.91 to 3.09. (3-.09 to 3+.09)

```{r echo=FALSE}
iris_data <- iris

```

## Problem 4 - Linear Equations from OLS model

1. Using the statistical output on the previous slide, derive an equation to find the Y or dependent variable (Sepal.Length) for any value of X (Sepal.Width).
2. Using the equation you derived, what is the predicted Sepal.Length for a Sepal.Width of 3.5?
3. Using the equation you derived, what is the predicted Sepal.Length for a Sepal.Width of 4.0?

## Problem 4 - Solution

- The basic equation for a linear model is $Y = \alpha + \beta X$ where Y is the dependent variable, X is the independent variable, $\alpha$ is the intercept, and \$beta$, the slope of the line, is the coefficient for the X variable.

1. Answer: Sepal.Length = 6.526 - 0.223 * Sepal.Width

## Problem 4 - Solution

1. Answer: Sepal.Length = 6.526 - 0.223 * Sepal.Width
2. Answer: Sepal.Length = 6.526 - 0.223 * 3.5 = 5.7455
3. Answer: Sepal.Length = 6.526 - 0.223 * 4.0 = 5.634

## Problem 5 - Linear Equations from OLS model

```{r echo=FALSE}
model2 <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Petal.Length, data = iris_data)
stargazer(model2, type = "text")


```
<p style="background-color: crimson; color: #f1f1f1; font-size: small">From *iris* data set in R.</p>


## Problem 5 - Linear Equations from OLS model

1. Using the statistical output on the previous slide, derive an equation to find the Y or dependent variable (Sepal.Length) for any value of X (Petal.Length).

2. Using the equation you derived, what is the predicted Sepal.Length for a Petal.Length of 3.5?

3. Using the equation you derived, what is the predicted Sepal.Length for a Petal.Length of 4.0?

## Problem 5 - Solution

1. Answer: Sepal.Length = 4.307 + 0.409 * Petal.Length
2. Answer: Sepal.Length = 4.307 + 0.409 * 3.5 = 5.739
3. Answer: Sepal.Length = 4.307 + 0.409 * 4.0 = 5.943


## Problem 6 - Linear Equations from OLS model with more than two X variables

```{r echo=FALSE}
model3 <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width + Petal.Length, data = iris_data)
stargazer(model3, type = "text")
```
<p style="background-color: crimson; color: #f1f1f1; font-size: small">From *iris* data set in R.</p>


## Problem 6 - Linear Equations from OLS model with more than two X variables

1. Using the statistical output on the previous slide, derive an equation to find the Y or dependent variable (Sepal.Length) for any value of X (Sepal.Width and Petal.Length).

2. Using the previous equation find the predicted Sepal.Length for a Sepal.Width of 3.5 and a Petal.Length of 4.0.

## Problem 6 - Solution

1. Answer: Sepal.Length = 2.2469 + 0.596 * Sepal.Width + 0.472 * Petal.Length
2. Answer: Sepal.Length = 2.2469 + 0.596 * 3.5 + 0.472 * 4.0 = 6.221

## Problem 7 - Linear Equations from OLS model with more than two X variables

1. Using the statistical output on the previous slides, derive an equation to find the Y or dependent variable (Sepal.Length) for any value of X (Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, and Petal.Width).
2. Using the above equation, find the predicted Sepal.Length for a Sepal.Width of 3.5 for mean values of the other X variables.
3. Using the above equation, find the predicted Sepal.Length for a Sepal.Width of 4.5 for mean values of the other X variables.

## Problem 7 - Solution

1. Answer: Sepal.Length = 1.856 + 0.651 * Sepal.Width + 0.709 * Petal.Length - 0.556 * Petal.Width
2. Answer: Sepal.Length = 1.856 + 0.651 * 3.5 + 0.709 * 3.76 - 0.556 * 1.199 = 6.134
3. Answer: Sepal.Length = 1.856 + 0.651 * 4.5 + 0.709 * 3.76 - 0.556 * 1.199 = 6.785
